image.altText: Police vehicles are seen near the location of a reported shooting.

items.synopsis: Two people have been killed and a male offender is dead after a serious incident unfolded at a construction site in Auckland's CBD this morning.

title.children: Gunman shot dead after killing two in attack on Auckland CBD construction site

image.altText: a generic shot of Auckland cbd

items.synopsis: New Zealand police say a shooting which has left three people dead in World Cup host city Auckland is an isolated incident. Follow live.

title.children: Auckland shooting on eve of World Cup 'not a national security risk'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Chris Hipkins has confirmed six other people have been injured and taken to Auckland hospital. The offender was armed with a pump-action shotgun. Mr Hipkins said the man moved through the building site discharging the firearm as he went. Upon reaching the upper levels of the building, he contained himself in an elevator, shots were fired and he was located a short time later. "I want to thank the brave men and women of the New Zealand police, who ran into the gunfire, straight into harm's way in order to save the lives of others," he said. "These kind of situations move fast and the actions of those who risk their lives to save others are nothing short of heroic."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prime Minister Chris Hipkins is speaking

children.content: Prime Minister Chris Hipkins has confirmed six other people have been injured and taken to Auckland hospital.
The offender was armed with a pump-action shotgun.
Mr Hipkins said the man moved through the building site discharging the firearm as he went.
Upon reaching the upper levels of the building, he contained himself in an elevator, shots were fired and he was located a short time later.
"I want to thank the brave men and women of the New Zealand police, who ran into the gunfire, straight into harm's way in order to save the lives of others," he said.
"These kind of situations move fast and the actions of those who risk their lives to save others are nothing short of heroic."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We will bring you updates from the press conference with New Zealand Prime Minister Chris Hipkins shortly. Watch the stream here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NZ prime minister to speak in 15 minutes

children.content: We will bring you updates from the press conference with New Zealand Prime Minister Chris Hipkins shortly.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Police have contained a serious incident that unfolded at a construction site in Auckland’s CBD this morning. Police say there has been multiple injuries and two people are confirmed to have died. The male offender is also dead. Police are reassuring the public that the shooting is an isolated incident and not a national security risk.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Two people confirmed dead

children.content: Police have contained a serious incident that unfolded at a construction site in Auckland’s CBD this morning.
Police say there has been multiple injuries and two people are confirmed to have died.
The male offender is also dead.
Police are reassuring the public that the shooting is an isolated incident and not a national security risk.

image.altText: A two-storey building behind a mesh fence.

items.synopsis: Reports of mould, asbestos and bug infestations have prompted a SafeWork SA review of Adelaide's Pregnancy Advisory Centre.

title.children: 'Someone will be hurt': Urgent inspections amid safety concerns at SA Health clinic

image.altText: An SA Ambulance Service sign on the side of a vehicle with another in the background saying Emergency Ambulance

items.synopsis: The 41-year-old man was rushed to hospital after the crash on a bike track at Woodcroft on Sunday morning but died on Tuesday, police said.

title.children: Mountain bike rider dies days after crash in Adelaide's south

image.altText: A man with beard wearing white t-shirt with graphic in a backyard

items.synopsis: A South Australian man, charged with criminal neglect after allegedly submerging an infant in a motel sink filled with hot water, is remanded in custody. Warning: This story contains content that some readers may find distressing.

title.children: Uncle denied bail after allegedly shoving two-year-old into scalding water

image.altText: Composite image of Daniel Andrews and Kereyn Smith.

items.synopsis: Commonwealth Games Federation vice-president Kereyn Smith questions Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews's integrity over his decision to axe the 2026 Games.

title.children: 'Unprecedented': Games VP challenges Daniel Andrews's version of events on cancellation

image.altText: A middle-aged white woman with short grey hair. She is standing by a door, wearing a blue sweater

items.synopsis: Jenny Moncur's husband Royce died in 2014 after being diagnosed with cancer. Almost a decade later, she was still being contacted about his Telstra account.

title.children: 'Like a Monty Python skit': Telstra 'harassed' Jenny for nine years over her dead husband's account

image.altText: Marnus Labuschagne holds the bridge of his nose in frustration while walking off the field

items.synopsis: Predicted rain means this critical fourth Ashes Test could be compressed into three days' worth of play, only adding to the frustration of Australia's batting performance on day one.

title.children: Australia can't close the door on England as Ashes remain alive in Test forced into fast-forward

image.altText: Lucas Beattie is among the youngest patients to receive gene therapy for Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy

items.synopsis: There's no known cure for the genetic condition Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy but a world-first treatment trial is being hailed as a potential "game changer" for children like Lucas.

title.children: Lucas was facing life in a wheelchair until a medical trial gave his parents hope

image.altText: A woman in a winter coat and glasses.

items.synopsis: The lawyer for Raelene Polymiadis, who is accused of murdering her parents by injecting them with her own insulin, tells an Adelaide court her client's diabetes has been misdiagnosed by prison health authorities.

title.children: Woman accused of killing 94yo parents with insulin says prison authorities are mistreating her diabetes

image.altText: A thin snake with grey on the top half and yellow scales on bottom half coiled on the dirt

items.synopsis: A new venomous species of snake is discovered after being mistaken as a different species for decades, researchers say.

title.children: New venomous species of desert snake discovered through genetic research

image.altText: A car next to a cricket pitch.

items.synopsis: A man who drove a stolen car through an Adelaide cricket game, with police in pursuit, is sentenced to up to six years in jail by a judge who said he had demonstrated "terrifying and wanton disregard" for public safety.

title.children: Axe-wielding driver who sped across cricket oval in stolen Holden gets six years in jail

image.altText: An elderly woman in a church

items.synopsis: NSW Police allege in court documents Senior Constable Kristian White's decision to deploy his taser on the elderly woman "does not meet the threshold" of acceptable use for officers.

title.children: Officer said 'na bugger it' before tasering 95yo Clare Nowland, court documents allege

image.altText: A glowing sign with the letters AI at a conference.

items.synopsis: Internet users are bypassing China's great firewall to connect with a US-made chatbot, as Beijing releases rules paving the way for the country's generative AI boom.

title.children: ChatGPT is blocked in China but techies are creating ways to get around restrictions

image.altText: Copy of Shadows

items.synopsis: Women's football started with sell-out crowds in the 1920s, only to be banned a year later. Through five decades of darkness, football's pioneers carried the torch for future generations.

title.children: Out of the shadows: How women's football flourished after 50 years of darkness

image.altText: The Olympic rings pictured in front of the IOC headquarters in Lausanne, Switzerland.

items.synopsis: Victoria hardly had to beat rival contenders for the now-dumped 2026 Commonwealth Games, a far cry from the prize fight bidding war for the coveted Olympics. It begs the question — which event is preferable to host?

title.children: Are the Commonwealth Games really so hard to host?

image.altText: A close up shot of Daniel Andrews face during a media conference.

items.synopsis: Given the scepticism over the new Commonwealth Games costings and the outcry from athletes and regional communities, the pressure to release the analysis the Victorian premier is relying on will only build, writes David Speers.

title.children: The $6 billion canary in a cost-of-living crisis: The mystery blowout that sank the Commonwealth Games

image.altText: an indigenous man standing next to a large canvas

items.synopsis: An indigenous artist and elder is "disgusted" that a painting he composed of Uluru has been reappropriated to help spread misinformation about the Voice to Parliament.

title.children: What we learnt trying to trace thousands of 'Vote No' flyers being posted across the country

image.altText: Education Minister Jason Clare stands at a lectern with a seated audience faced towards him.

items.synopsis: Students and safety advocates say the federal government needs to take immediate and substantial action to curtail sexual violence at universities.

title.children: Students call on federal government to tackle sexual violence at universities

image.altText: Soldiers tend a stationary cannon underneath camouflage netting.

items.synopsis: An Australian man serving on the frontline with the Ukrainian International Legion is alleging that Australians, Ukrainians and other volunteers are being put in danger and threatened with repercussions for speaking out by some incompetent Ukrainian commanders.

title.children: 'It's a meat grinder': Aussie whistleblower claims some Ukrainian Legion commanders are putting soldiers in danger

image.altText: A woman in a grocery isle of fruit and vegetables

items.synopsis: Inflation might be tracking down, but many of us are still feeling the price pinch — particularly at the supermarket. Here are some ways to make your groceries go further and last longer.

title.children: How you store fresh produce could mean less food waste — which means saving money

image.altText: Two dingoes on the beach at Fraser Island, with one wearing a GPS tracking collar.

items.synopsis: One of the dingoes involved in the attack of a young woman on K'gari earlier this week has been destroyed. The animal was also responsible for the hospitalisation of a six-year-old girl in April.

title.children: Rangers 'humanely euthanase' dingo responsible for attacks on K'gari (Fraser Island)

image.altText: An aerial view of several large buildings and some car parks, with one building highlighted in red.

items.synopsis: A disability supporter provider has been able to buy back a property it previously owned for the bargain price of $1, thanks to the long memory of an employee.

title.children: 'Amazing deal': Prime Tasmanian real estate bought for $1 after disability provider remembers sale clause

image.altText: Peopole of all ages are walking outdoors, wearing blue surgical masks.

items.synopsis: One in five people who test positive for COVID don't get symptoms. This could be explained by a genetic variant and exposure to the common cold, a new study suggests.

title.children: Have you tested positive for COVID but had no symptoms? Scientists find a gene that could explain why

image.altText: A tall brown apartment building

items.synopsis: In 2018, Canada's British Columbia introduced a tax against vacant homes. Three years later, more than 20,000 rentals were back on the market.

title.children: Could a tax against empty homes help end Australia's housing crisis?

image.altText: Logos of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.

items.synopsis: Far from improving our lives, a growing body of economic evidence is pointing the finger at big tech as a major factor in economic stagnation and lower wage growth.

title.children: Are we all paying the price for 'superstar' firms?

image.altText: Jonny Bairstow is hugged

items.synopsis: After a series of missed chances Jonny Bairstow finally shows his value behind the stumps, and the sun causes play to be stopped. Here are the five things you missed from day one of the fourth Ashes Test.

title.children: Five quick hits — Bairstow takes a screamer and the sun stops play at Old Trafford

image.altText: A golden logo of a crown made up of dots sits on the side of a blue-tinted glass building.

items.synopsis: Crown's chief financial officer used details of the casino giant's cash-flow woes to argue down a penalty from financial crimes agency AUSTRAC.

title.children: Crown blamed previous fines, threatened bankruptcy as it tried to shrink AUSTRAC penalty

image.altText: A serious elderly woman with short grey hair, whtie and grey top, and pink coat in front of old veranda.

items.synopsis: This 89-year-old thought she was getting a "good deal" when a salesman knocked on her door in the late 1960s and offered to install new insulation on her roof. Now she has lung cancer.

title.children: Aileen has been unknowingly living in an asbestos-contaminated house. She fears others may be too

image.altText: A sign for Big W

items.synopsis: Yumi Stynes and Melissa Kang's sex education guide for teens is a topic of hot debate for its frankness. It also provides comprehensive, inclusive sex education that combats misinformation.

title.children: A teen sex ed book has been removed from Big W shelves to protect staff from abuse. This is what's actually inside

image.altText: General manager Tricia Ong packing dog treats.

items.synopsis: Australians took to online shopping with gusto during the pandemic, but now they need to brace for rising costs as deliveries become much more expensive.

title.children: There are several reasons why your online shopping may be getting more expensive — this is one

image.altText: Thai police in dark uniforms stand in lines blocking a road, with large buildings nearby.

items.synopsis: Pita Limjaroenrat was the only candidate for leader of his party, which was the top finisher in May's general election, and was hoping to have another tilt but opponents say he was unqualified to run due to owning shares in a media company.

title.children: Thai parliament voids nomination of leading prime ministerial hopeful

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin's face is illuminated by a streetlight as he partially smiles through the window of a car, rolled down

items.synopsis: Mr Prigozhin's mutiny, which posed the most serious threat to President Vladimir Putin's 23-year rule, was billed by the mercenary chief as being aimed at ousting Russia's top military leaders whom he accused of incompetence.

title.children: Video appears to show Russian mercenary chief Prigozhin for first time since mutiny
